column1: #FORMAT=WebAnno TSV 3.3
#T_SP=webanno.custom.StanzaNER|value
#T_RL=webanno.custom.Relationships|Relationship|BT_webanno.custom.StanzaNER
#Text=The Aidonia Treasure is a collection of Mycenaean gold and jewelry returned to Greece in 1996 and thought to have been robbed from a cemetery at Aidonia in the late 1970s .
#Text=Aidonia is a village ten kilometres northwest of Nemea in the northeastern Peloponnesian district of Corinthia in Greece .

#Text=In November 1976 , a Mycenaean ( fifteenth-century BC ) cemetery was discovered not far from the village , and the tombs were dug out illegally by local archaiokapiloi ( a term used for looters in Greece ) .
#Text=There were reports of a gun battle between rival gangs of archaiokapiloi , and evidence that local government officials had sanctioned and even participated in the plunder .
#Text=Looted objects were rumoured to have been smuggled out of Greece hidden in watermelons .
#Text=In November 1977 , the Greek Archaeological Service assigned a guard to the site , and in Spring 1978 it commenced official excavations .
#Text=Twenty chamber tombs were discovered , but only two had survived untouched .
#Text=The remaining eighteen tombs had been largely emptied of their contents , though in one , the looters had overlooked a pit dug into the floor of the tomb .
#Text=After excavation , it was found to contain an assemblage of gold jewelry .
#Text=( Mycenaean chamber tombs typically contain several interments and may be richly furnished with pottery , metalwork and jewelry ) .

#Text=Nothing much was heard outside Greece about the plundered Aidonia cemetery until April 1993 , when New York ’ s Michael Ward Gallery offered on display for sale a collection comprising approximately fifty items of Mycenean gold jewelry and sealstones .

#Text=A catalogue accompanying the display entitled Gold of the Mycenaeans , with an introduction and object descriptions by archaeologist John Betts , could only offer ‘ a European collector ’ for provenance .

#Text=Potential customers were reassured by the catalogue , however , that gold analyses conducted by Jack Ogden of the Cambridge Centre for Precious Metal Research had guaranteed the authenticity of the material , and that in reply to a written enquiry the Greek Ministry of Culture had confirmed that the material was not stolen .
#Text=The asking price for the assemblage was US $ 1.5 million .
#Text=On 4 April 1993 , the display was trailed in the New York Times , where the objects were described as ‘ rare gold baubles : small , ancient and radiant ’ .
#Text=Two days later , on 6 April , archaeologist Ricardo Elia alerted the Consul General of Greece in New York to the material on display .
#Text=On 27 April 1993 , archaeologist James Wright , who had worked at Nemea , informed the Greek Archaeological Service of his suspicion that the material might have been looted from Aidonia .
#Text=After obtaining a copy of the catalogue , the Greek Ministry of Culture convened a committee of experts to investigate the possible origin of the material .

#Text=The committee concluded that because of close stylistic and technical affinities between objects excavated legitimately at Aidonia and those offered for sale in New York , the New York material must have been looted from Aidonia .
#Text=The Ministry of Culture also recognized that it had received a letter in 1992 from an Athenian lawyer asking for information about the objects , though not mentioning the name of Michael Ward .

#Text=The Ministry had responded that while there was no evidence to show that the material had been illegally excavated or stolen from a museum , if any such evidence should become available then Greece reserved the right to ask for the material ’ s return .
#Text=On 14 May 1993 , attorneys acting on behalf of Greece notified Ward that the material was the property of Greece and asked for its return .
#Text=On 25 May they obtained an injunction from the US District Court , Southern District of New York , preventing the sale or transport out the state of the material , and sued for its return .
#Text=On 30 December 1993 , an out-of-court settlement was announced whereby Ward undertook to donate the material to the US-based Society for the Preservation of the Greek Heritage ( SPGH ) .
#Text=By donating the material to the charitable SPGH instead of directly to Greece , Ward was able to claim a tax deduction for the purchase price of the material , said to be $ 150,000 .
#Text=Because Ward was a dealer , he was limited to claiming the cost to himself of acquiring the material .
#Text=If he had been a collector , he would have been able to claim its fair market value , thought by Ward to be $ 1.5 million .
#Text=The SPGH returned the material to Greece in 1996 .
#Text=The settlement between Greece and Ward was welcomed by some commentators , but there have also been expressions of regret that the case never proceeded to court .
#Text=On the positive side , the settlement secured the return of what was most likely illicit material to Greece .
#Text=Ward avoided the large financial loss that he would have incurred if the court had decided against his ownership .
#Text=Both sides minimized their legal fees .
#Text=By settling out-of-court , however , any information possessed by Ward about the material ’ s provenance remained a private matter .
#Text=It is thought unlikely that the material offered by Ward and recovered by Greece represents the totality of the material looted from Aidonia .
#Text=There was no pottery , for example .
#Text=Without more information about provenance , there is little hope of locating and recovering the remainder .
#Text=In the absence of reliable provenance , it has also been argued that the source of the recovered material is far from definite .

#Text=The Aidonia provenience was established on the basis of stylistic and technical similarities , but while these similarities might suggest an area of common manufacture , they do not necessarily indicate a place of joint deposition .
#Text=The objects acquired by Ward might possibly have been found elsewhere .

#Text=If the case had gone to court , uncertainties surrounding the method used to establish source would probably have been exploited , and it is possible that they would have fatally undermined Greece ’ s case .

#Text=These lingering doubts about source also make it potentially misleading to lump together the material obtained through legitimate excavation with that recovered from Ward as a singular ‘ treasure ’ .

#Text=Again , if the provenance of the material had been resolved in a court of law , using evidence apart from that of the objects themselves , the status of the ‘ treasure ’ would have been made more secure , to the benefit of archaeological scholarship .
#Text=Ward later claimed that Greece had concocted a provenance and that US archaeologists had embarrassed Greece into taking action .
#Text=After the looting had ended , the residents of Aidonia fell to feuding amongst themselves , and the village was largely abandoned .
#Text=New tombs are believed to have been robbed there in 2002 and 2004 .

#Text=The Greek journalist Nikos Zirganos has compared what happened at Aidonia unfavourably to nearby Nemea , where finds from a long-term programme of archaeological excavation and research are curated in a purpose-built museum for the benefit of the general public .
